data.title: The all-candidates-inclusive US presidential preference poll

data.text:
I thought it might be interesting to see a poll for president which included all candidates that will appear on a ballot, even those without a realistic chance of winning. I made my list primarily using this Wikipedia page, which includes links to nearly all of the candidates' web sites so you can read up on any with which you are not familiar. If you are ineligible (not American, too young, etc), please choose one of the options made for you at the top of the list. This section been trimmed to the two majors and 'other'. I put these options at the top so they'd be spotted even by those who didn't bother to read my introduction. -- View image here: https://cdn.arstechnica.net/forum/smilies/biggrin_classic.gif --
This is a poll for who you actually intend to vote for (except those who cannot vote, of course).

Hopefully I didn't miss anyone. -- View image here: http://episteme.arstechnica.com/groupee_common/emoticons/icon_smile.gif -- If it appears that it will be close, I will lightly hold my nose and vote for Obama and Biden.

Another poster put it just about the way I look at it. Our choice is between a slightly stale peanut butter sandwich or a fresh, hot, open face steaming shit sandwich.

If Obama and Biden have it in the bag, I'll be casting a vote for Ralph Nader (since Dennis Kucinich is not on the ballot).

I cannot find the words to express my disappointment with the closed political system in the US.

OTOH, the MSM + general public have done nothing that would indicate a capability of handling the responsibilities that come with real choice and real debate about real issues (domestic and international).

The conservatives and specifically the Republicans seem to like a stupid / uninformed electorate. The Democrats to a lesser degree. Both parties have a joint strangle hold on the system.

. If I actually thought my vote might count for something (or even be counted without being lost in the mail), I'd go ahead and send in an absentee ballot.

However, since probably about 98% of the vote will go between D and R, my vote and voice are essentially useless anyway. If we had some kind of preferential voting system, I might be more inclined to put in my vote, but as it stands, it's just a waste of my time.

I know I'm taking the lazy, cowardly way, but I don't see the team sport method of American politics going away ever. Those with the power are too entrenched and would never pass any reforms that might give others the chance to get in power.

Hence the reason I no longer live in the United States.

I don't know who you would vote for, but voting for a third-party or independent candidate is much more important than voting for a sure loser (i.e. John McCain in MA) or a sure winner (i.e. Barack Obama in IL). AFAIK, if a third party candidate gets 5% or more of the popular vote (nationwide, regardless of their status on the ballot in every state), they (or their party) will be eligible for federal public funding in the next election. That would go a very long way towards breaking the current red/blue system if you're not happy with it.

I live in CA, and I'll vote for Obama, because he truly is a great candidate in my mind, and I do not have a problem with a strong two-party system. Outside of Obama, I'd vote for Nader or Ron Paul.

For reference, Nader received 2.75% of the vote in 2000, which was almost 3 million votes. To get 5% would require over 5 million, the exact number being subject to voter turnout. That's not actually that large of a number, and I suspect that if more people were aware that their third party candidates can receive some sort of victory even without actually winning the election, more people would cast their votes that way.

Do I choose the state I was last a resident of? (if 5 years is enough for residency, then FL, otherwise, PA for 8 years 12 years ago)

Do I choose the state where my mother lives? (TN, but I've never lived there)

Or my father?
(IL, but I haven't lived there for 20 years)

Do I choose the state that I use for my permanent address on my various immigration forms in the various countries I've visited or lived in? (MA, where my sister lives or TN where my mother lives, depending on which forms we talk about... and I've lived in neither)

Anyway, since I probably won't live in the USA again (it's a big world with a lot of interesting places and I feel no particular attachment), my interest in US politics is primarily intellectual, unless the threat of bombs dropping becomes real whereever I happen to be (yes there is more to it than that). So, I'm not really worried about it.

You're asking the wrong person. But if the politics doesn't matter to you, then that is fine as well. The right to not vote is just as important as the right to vote. I was merely providing some useful information for the massive number of people out there who choose not to vote.

I'm not checking these numbers, but as I recall, voter turnout is about 60% usually. with 300 million people in the US, there have to be at least 250 million eligible voters. that means there are somewhere more than 80 million people who don't vote. If even a small fraction of that (1 in 20) were to cast their vote for a single third party candidate, it could vastly change the politics of the United States.

Just pointing these out because I was curious.

Good point, but my guess of 60% turnout and 250 million eligible voters wasn't so far off.

I'd be interested in a serious study of that 40% who don't vote. Of course, since they don't vote, it's hard to figure that out since they aren't at the exit polls or anything.

I see the following groups a non-voter could fall into:

1) Don't care/apathetic
2) Don't know they can vote
3) Don't feel informed enough to make a decision
4) Feel vote is worthless (i.e. in MA or AL)
5) Disgruntled with the system, no good major candidates (also could fall into (4))
6) Forgot to vote, didn't know where to vote
7) Didn't have time on election day

There might be more, but those seem to be the obvious ones. If even a small proportion of these 50 million+ non-voters were in category 5, (just 1 in 10), they could make a real difference if they understood the way things work. i'm one of those i guess 40% non voters.

for one i'm in KY, so it'll be mccain all the way except in the city i live in, but it won't make a difference.

i don't like the system, and well, don't care either. it's fun reading these threads and all, but at the end of the day, all of em are fuckers and i couldn't care less who the hell america votes in. as we've seen, the election seems to hinge more on cult of personality than anything solid, so meh.

but i do get election day off work. that's a plus in my book. -- View image here: http://episteme.arstechnica.com/groupee_common/emoticons/icon_smile.gif --
